title: "What are the effects of involuntary movements and suggested sensations in hypnotized subjects?"
first_phrase: In the preceding text, the author explores the effects of imitation on subjects and the inhibition of certain movements despite the subject's intense desire to perform them. The author also discusses how experiments were conducted on subjects to control their sensations of touch and taste and induce forgetfulness. The text concludes by stating that future studies are required to investigate the nature of the fluid action and willpower that underlie these phenomena. The last 200 tokens demonstrate how some subjects were placed in a state of extreme stiffness or somnambulism and were able to recall their experiences in this state during a lucid interval.

Assurément ces expériences sont très facilitées par la séparation aisée qui peut s’opérer, chez certains sujets, entre l’action de l’intelligence consciente et l’action de l’intelligence inconsciente, l’une pouvant être supprimée tandis que l’autre fonctionne et inversement; mais je ne me prononce absolument pas sur la nature de l’action fluide, volonté, etc., qui est à la base de ces phénomènes (2) et dont l’étude sera sans doute l’objet de travaux ultérieurs.
last_phrase: In conclusion, although certain individuals may experience extreme rigidity, sleepwalking, and selective memory loss during hypnosis, the nature of these phenomena is still subject to further research.
